question.title: Netty 4, Java 7 JVM SIGSEGV crash under load

node.contents: Netty 4.0.21 is out. Have you tried that on the off chance it fixes it?

astNode.text: Netty 4.0.21 is out. Have you tried that on the off chance it fixes it?

node.contents: Using Netty 4.0.21 may have fixed it. Previously a connection would receive ~150,000 messages (200bytes) and then crash the JVM. But it appears to get past that now and behave as expected. Thanks! Any idea what the fix may have been?

astNode.text: Using Netty 4.0.21 may have fixed it. Previously a connection would receive ~150,000 messages (200bytes) and then crash the JVM. But it appears to get past that now and behave as expected. Thanks! Any idea what the fix may have been?

node.contents: No idea. Just when I get a bug like this I always make sure I'm using the latest version. If you reported it to the netty devs it is probably the first thing they would suggest.

astNode.text: No idea. Just when I get a bug like this I always make sure I'm using the latest version. If you reported it to the netty devs it is probably the first thing they would suggest.

node.contents: I can reliably reproduce this now. I found that the issue was present in 4.0.18.Final and 4.0.19.Final. It was not in 4.0.20.Final and 4.0.21.Final. So the fix was likely in 4.0.20.Final.

astNode.text: I can reliably reproduce this now. I found that the issue was present in 4.0.18.Final and 4.0.19.Final. It was not in 4.0.20.Final and 4.0.21.Final. So the fix was likely in 4.0.20.Final.

node.contents: I have a binary protocol implemented with Netty that is being performance tested, and the JVM is crashing with the below report. I do not know how to repeat the crash, but it does happen regularly and only under heavy load. I have the following dependencies:

astNode.text: I have a binary protocol implemented with Netty that is being performance tested, and the JVM is crashing with the below report. I do not know how to repeat the crash, but it does happen regularly and only under heavy load. I have the following dependencies:

node.contents: It appears that the array copy is occurring in the nioEventLoopGroup thread. The performance test I am running is sending a large number of small messages over ~50 TCP connections. Where a large number is about 1 million 200 byte messages per connection. Each message has 2 response messages sent back.

astNode.text: It appears that the array copy is occurring in the nioEventLoopGroup thread. The performance test I am running is sending a large number of small messages over ~50 TCP connections. Where a large number is about 1 million 200 byte messages per connection. Each message has 2 response messages sent back.

node.contents: This is what I am doing to create Netty:

elements.contents: protected void initChannel(SocketChannel ch) throws Exception { log.info("initChannel(SocketChannel ch) {} {} ",ch,this); ch.pipeline() .addLast(new IpFilterHandler()) .addLast(new ProtocolEncoder()) .addLast(new LengthFieldBasedFrameDecoder(4 * 1024, 0, 4, -4, 0)) .addLast(new ProtocolDecoder()) .addLast(new WindowingHandler()) .addLast(new SequenceNumberAssignmentHandler()) .addLast("idleState", new IdleStateHandler(idleTime, idleTime, idleTime)) .addLast("idleDisconnect", m_idleDisconnectHandler) .addLast("auth", m_authHandler) .addLast("catchall", new CatchallHandler(false)); ch.config().setAllocator(PooledByteBufAllocator.DEFAULT); ch.config().setAutoRead(true); log.info("finished initChannel(SocketChannel ch) {} {} ",ch,this); }

node.contents: After initial connection the pipeline is altered again in the authHandler

astNode.text: After initial connection the pipeline is altered again in the authHandler

elements.contents: @Override protected void channelRead0(ChannelHandlerContext ctx, CustomMessage msg) throws Exception { ResponseMessage response = auth(msg,ctx); ctx.pipeline().replace("auth", "msghandler", new MessageHandler()); ctx.pipeline().replace("idleState", "inactivityPeriod", new IdleStateHandler()); ctx.pipeline().addAfter("msghandler", "responsehandler", new ResponseHandler()); ctx.pipeline().addAfter("responsehandler", "heartbeat", new HeartbeatHandler()); ctx.pipeline().addAfter("heartbeat", "disconnect", new DisconnectHandler()); ctx.channel().closeFuture().addListener(new CleanupChannelFutureListener(ctx)); ctx.writeAndFlush(response); }

node.contents: What is the best way to find out what is causing this SIGSEGV in the JVM?

astNode.text: What is the best way to find out what is causing this SIGSEGV in the JVM?

node.contents:
Netty 4.x heavily uses Unsafe API - Oracle JDK internal API that allows raw memory access.
See PlatformDependent0.java from Netty sources.

astNode.text:
Netty 4.x heavily uses Unsafe API - Oracle JDK internal API that allows raw memory access.
See PlatformDependent0.java from Netty sources.

node.contents: The crash log tells that the problem happens inside Unsafe.copyMemory call where the target is a byte[] array in Java Heap young generation, and the source points to an unmapped memory region. Most likely this is caused by an attempt to get bytes from a native buffer that has been previously released. There are no sanity checks inside Unsafe API, so any misuse typically ends up with a JVM crash.

astNode.text: The crash log tells that the problem happens inside Unsafe.copyMemory call where the target is a byte[] array in Java Heap young generation, and the source points to an unmapped memory region. Most likely this is caused by an attempt to get bytes from a native buffer that has been previously released. There are no sanity checks inside Unsafe API, so any misuse typically ends up with a JVM crash.

node.contents: Upgrading from Netty 4.0.18.Final to 4.0.20.Final fixed this issue.

astNode.text: Upgrading from Netty 4.0.18.Final to 4.0.20.Final fixed this issue.
